I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  A key lesson from the 1997–1998 Asian financial crisis is that mature bond markets are 
crucial  for maintaining  a  better  balance  within  financial sectors  and  thus  building  financial 
stability in the region. Regional and national initiatives have focused on removing obstacles to 
bond market development, including inadequate or weak credit rating systems. Since 1987, the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) has supported Asian domestic credit rating agencies (DCRAs) 
through  equity  investments  for  their  establishment.1  DCRAs  can  support  ADB’s  thrust  in 
promoting  infrastructure  development  in  Asia  since  a  better  flow  of  information  stimulates 
growth  of  the  sector.  This  growth  can  facilitate  more  domestic  resource  mobilization 
opportunities,  especially  for  infrastructure  development,  as  investors  prefer  to  rely  on  the 
opinion of DCRAs for their decisions. In September 2001, the Association of Credit Rating 
Agencies in Asia (ACRAA) was established to help harmonize credit rating processes for the 
development of the region’s bond markets. ADB has supported strengthening institutional and 
technical capacities of Asian DCRAs through ACRAA activities.2 The ASEAN+3 Asian Bond 
Markets  Initiative  (ABMI)—endorsed  at  the  meeting  of  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian 
Nations (ASEAN)+3 finance ministers in August 2003 to accelerate development of efficient and 
liquid bond markets in the region—established the ABMI Working Group (WG) 4 on Rating 
Systems,  which  ADB  has  supported  with    technical  expertise  on  current  issues  on  rating 
systems.  
 
2.  This  technical  assistance  (TA)3  aims  to  continue  ADB’s  support  in  strengthening 
institutional and technical capacities of Asian DCRAs, and to further contribute to promoting the 
policy  dialogue  for  enhancing  the  credibility  and  visibility  of  DCRAs  in  Asia,  especially  in 
fostering “comparability” among them. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  A  major  cause  of  the  Asian  financial  crisis,  maturity  mismatches  resulting  from 
overreliance  on  short-term  bank  financing  for  long-term  investment,  as  well  as  currency 
mismatches, could have been reduced if well-developed bond markets were an alternative 
avenue for channeling the region’s large savings into long-term investments. One of the critical 
requirements for efficient bond markets is to ensure both issuers and investors can avail of 
accurate informational frameworks—this is on top of contractual frameworks, the regulatory and 
supervisory frameworks, a diversified investor base, and issuing and trading processes based 
on pricing mechanisms.  
 
4.  Information  asymmetries  prevent  effective  and  efficient  direct  interaction  between 
multiple savers and investors. Sharing credit information is important to give equal opportunities 
to market participants and foster competition in the financial system. Credit reporting makes a

5.  The significance of DCRAs in developing efficient bond markets is their role in building 
informational frameworks for the financial system.  
 
(i)  For  investors.  Credit  ratings  support  investment  decisions.  Thus,  effective 
DCRAs are critical for bond market transparency and efficiency as they can 
optimize risk-return profiles for investors, help them monitor portfolios through 
regular surveillance and credit rating adjustments, and provide timely information 
to help in trading and risk management. 
(ii)  For issuers. DCRAs help issuers assess loan risk and raise funds under given 
market conditions, and encourage corporations to conform to prudent and best 
corporate practices. 
(iii)  For  other  financial  intermediaries.  DCRAs  can  provide  other  market 
participants  (such  as  commercial  banks)  additional  information  for  risk 
assessment on behalf of clients. 
(iv)  For regulators. Credit rating information can provide financial regulators and 
securities  market  supervisors  with  complementary  tools  for  more  efficient 
prudential regulation and supervision. 
 
6.  Twenty-seven DCRAS and 10 subsidiaries of global credit rating agencies (GCRAs) 
operate in ASEAN+3 countries; Taipei,China; and in Bangladesh, India, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka.  
DCRAs have a key advantage over the local 100%-owned GCRAs in in-depth knowledge and 
understanding of domestic operating environments, corporate climate, business practices, and 
culture. At the same time, DCRAs may have lower operational costs that translate into lower 
rating fees for issuers. However, DCRAs are often perceived as inadequate or are less trusted 
by international and regional investors. The view is that DCRAs are less independent; have 
lower quality analysts and, consequently analysis; and limited experience in ratings because 
they are confined to domestic economies.   
 
7.  ACRAA promotes exchange of ideas, experience, information, and skills among its 24 
members so as to improve DCRAs’ credibility and to harmonize credit rating processes. The 
ACRAA members list is provided as a supplementary appendix. ACRAA aims to enhance each 
credit rating agency’s credibility by providing reliable market information, and to promote the 
adoption of best practices and common standards to ensure high quality and comparability of 
ratings throughout the region.  
 
8.  ADB has provided support to build the capacity of DCRAs through ACRAA’s training 
workshops and best practices dialogues. The training workshops have been conducted at two 
levels—basic  and  advanced—to  make  the  courses  suitable  for  the  participants’  level  of 
knowledge, skills, and experience. Since June 2002, six basic training workshops and three 
advanced workshops have been held with more than 220 DCRA staff members participating. 
Evaluations for each workshop are prepared, and outcomes are monitored and assessed by the 
ACRAA training committee. ACRAA plans to continue holding two basic workshops and one 
advanced workshop each year. The best-practices dialogue is a forum where special issues and 
current business and rating practices that need revising, reinforcing, or improving are discussed. 
Following the dialogues, DCRAs adopt the recommendations and suggestions in the region. In 
2002, the ACRAA Best Practice Checklist and Code of Ethics were adopted by all members,

3
and in June 2006, the mandatory observance of the Table of Contents of the ACRAA Best- 
Practice Policy Manual,4 and the Action Plan for Harmonization (disclosure and publication of 
key information)5 was initiated. The long-term agenda for these dialogues is to develop tools for 
cross-agency and cross-border comparison of ratings, and to compile rating methodologies and 
databases of all ratings issued by agencies and of regulatory support measures across the 
regulatory environments of DCRAs. 
 
9.  The ASEAN+3 ABMI WG 4 Rating System aims to enhance the credibility and visibility 
of DCRAs in Asia, so as to foster comparability of credit ratings among them. ADB has been 
interacting with WG4 and has been facilitating policy dialogue by providing technical expertise. 
Vigorous  discussion  by  international  regulators  such  as  the  International  Organization  of 
Securities Commission (IOSCO) and Basel II on the regulatory framework for DCRAs will 
significantly affect DCRA fundamental business practices.6 With GCRAs currently dominating 
cross-border rating standardization, fostering DCRA comparability in credit ratings is a first step 
toward achieving the goal of ABMI WG4. The determinants of comparability and elements of 
common standards include the following:  
 
(i)  Default studies. Encouraging DCRAs to publish or disclose historical default 
rates for the rating symbols they use and to collate data and publish annual 
default studies. DCRAs should also clearly outline “default” definitions. 
(ii)  Rating policies, methodologies, and practices. Requiring DCRAs to publish 
rating  policies  and  practices.  This  will  encourage  greater  comparability  and 
harmonization among themselves and GCRAs, and align them closer to the 
IOSCO code. It is worthwhile to explore having DCRAs publicly disclose (or 
establish) selected financial benchmarks—a practice already adopted by GCRAs. 
(iii)  Rating  database  and  disclosures.  Requiring  DCRAs  to  publish  the 
components of their rating database to allow for greater comparison. Each DCRA 
rating database is a function of local market dynamics and varies from one 
economy to another. 
  
10.  After the ABMI WG4 meeting in March 2006, the chair countries, Japan and Singapore, 
requested ADB to provide further support in (i) monitoring changes in the regulatory frameworks 
and requirements of DCRAs in Asia by introducing Basel II and IOSCO principles, and (ii) 
studying harmonization to enhance comparability in line with ASEAN+3 ABMI WG4.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The TA objective is to assist in strengthening the institutional and technical capacities of 
selected DCRAs in Asia, promoting regional cooperation among Asian DCRAs, and supporting 
the policy dialogue of ABMI WG4. The TA will support the enhancement of the credibility and 
visibility of DCRAs in Asia by strengthening their analytical capability, enhancing the disclosure 
of  key  information,  and  adopting  the  best-practice  code  of  conduct.  The  TA  will  increase 
transparency  and  efficiency  of  bond  markets  by  supporting  prudent  credit  ratings  and 
institutional capacity of DCRAs as they adapt to the new IOSCO regulatory framework principles 
and Basel II. The TA will also support harmonization of credit ratings among DCRAs in Asia and 
establishing comparability with GCRAs by identifying a common standard of rating practices. 
The TA will facilitate regional financial cooperation, and improve corporate governance and 
financial market supervision, which are key components for financial market stability in the 
region, and thus support key result areas of the Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI).  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will have three components: 
 
(i)  Enhancing  technical  competency  and  institutional  capacity  of  selected 
DCRAs in Asia. The TA will finance the organization and holding of training 
workshops and best-practices dialogues for staff and management of DCRAs 
(from ACRAA members) from 11 developing member economies:7 Bangladesh; 
People’s Republic of China; India; Indonesia; Malaysia; Pakistan; Philippines; Sri 
Lanka; Taipei,China; Thailand; and Uzbekistan. The ACRAA training workshops 
will  be  conducted  at  basic  and  advanced  levels  to  adapt  the  courses  to 
participants’  level  of  knowledge,  skill,  and  experience.  The  best-practices 
dialogues will discuss special issues and current business and rating practices 
that require revision, reinforcement, or improvement. Thereafter, the DCRAs will 
adopt the recommendations and suggestions resulting from the consensus of 
peers in the region. The long-term agenda for these dialogues is to develop tools 
for  comparing  cross-agency  and  cross-border  ratings,  and  to  compile  rating 
methodologies  and  databases  of  all  ratings  issued  by  agencies  and  the 
regulatory support measures promulgated across the regulatory environments of 
the participating DCRAs.  
(ii)  Monitoring and reporting on the status of regulatory frameworks for DCRA 
operations in selected Asian countries. The TA will monitor and report on the 
status of the implementation of IOSCO practices and Basel II guidelines by 
regulators in selected Asian countries. It will also monitor and report on the status 
of adopting a code of conduct (based on IOSCO practices) by DCRAs in the 
region, and the status of each DCRA against guidelines issued by regulators to 
qualify as an external credit assessment institution. The TA will compile the 
information and report on the impact of IOSCO practices and Basel II (steps 
taken by the selected DCRAs for complying with IOSCO Practices and Basel II 
requirements, along with capacity building). The TA will support the holding of an

(iii)  Enhancing comparability and harmonization among DCRAs in the region. 
The TA will explore the feasibility of developing common standards for credit 
rating  and  enhancing  comparability  among  DCRAs.  It  will  analyze  the 
comparability of the relative ratings of credit by DCRAs and those by GCRAs. 
The TA will analyze the credit rating methodology of DCRAs to determine the 
critical  rating  factors  in  identifying  common  rating  practices,  methodologies, 
databases, and policies among DCRAs, including specific financial benchmarks, 
rating databases, or other guiding factors used by each DCRA. The TA will also 
conduct a survey to establish the viability of a DCRA’s default study, which is a 
major component for developing common standards.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $600,000. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The cost will cover 
remuneration, travel, and per diem for international and national consultants. It will also cover 
the cost of the training workshops and best-practices dialogues: honoraria and travel expenses 
of resource persons,  hotel accommodation and subsistence allowance of the participants, and 
payment for venue and training materials. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB  will  be  the  TA  Executing  Agency  and  OREI  will  implement  the  TA  in  close 
collaboration with ACRAA. For enhancing technical competency and institutional capacity of 
selected DCRAs in Asia, OREI, jointly with ACRAA, will conceptualize and organize the training 
workshops and best-practices dialogues, and monitor and review the impact of the planned 
activities. For the other components of the TA, international and national consultants will be 
engaged. No activities financed under the TA may be held in a developing member country 
(DMC) unless ADB receives a no-objection letter from such DMC. 
 
15.  The TA will require approximately 10 person-months of international and 5 person-
months of national consulting services. The TA will be implemented over 12 months, starting 
January  2007  and  ending  December  2007.  All  consultants  and  resource  persons  will  be 
engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB's Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants (April  2006,  as 
amended from time to time). Consultants will be engaged as individual consultants. The scope 
of work and outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3.  The outline of the 
study for the third component, enhancing comparability and harmonization among the DCRAs in 
the region, is in Appendix 4. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis for 
Capacity Building and Regional Cooperation of Selected Credit Rating Agencies in Asia, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Resource Persons (international, 1 person-month) 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require the services of resource persons (for a total of 
about  1  person-month)  who  are  experts  in  credit  rating  services,  securitization,  corporate 
finance, and financial/bond market development, which are subjects of workshops and best-
practices dialogues of the Association of Credit Rating Agencies in Asia (ACRAA). The resource 
persons will have the following responsibilities: 
(i)   Design and develop training workshops or best-practices dialogues if necessary, 
and prepare detailed outlines for them. 
(ii)   Collate and prepare materials for participants. 
(iii)   Conduct training workshops. 
(iv)   Prepare  reports  on  activities  during  the  training  workshop  or  best-practice 
dialogues.  Include  the  activity  outline,  participant  profiles,  responses  and 
outcomes, lessons learned, overall impressions, evaluations of the workshops or 
the best-practice dialogues in relation to the TA objectives, and remaining issues 
and suggestions for possible follow-up activities. 
 
B.  Credit Rating Agency Regulatory Specialist (international, 4 person-months) 
2.  The responsibilities of the specialist are as follows:  
(i)  Monitor  and  report  on  the  status  of  the  implementation  of  International 
Organization  of  Securities  Commission  (IOSCO)  practices  and  Basel  II 
guidelines by regulators in selected Asian countries.  
(ii)  Review and monitor the compliance of domestic credit rating agencies (DCRA) 
with the IOSCO Code of Fundamentals, and other IOSCO-prescribed practices; 
evaluate  the  effectiveness  of  the  system  of  compliance  or  manner  of 
enforcement,  and  assess  the  positive  or  negative  effects  of  such  IOSCO 
prescriptions on DCRAs and the rating industry. 
(iii)  Review and monitor the implementation of Basel II Accord provisions affecting 
DCRAs especially as regards rating practices of selected DCRAs; survey the 
implementation by local regulatory authorities of the provisions on qualifying as 
external  credit  assessment  institutions;  and  evaluate  the  usefulness, 
reasonableness, and effectiveness of such Basel II prescriptions in enhancing  
credit rating practices and in reinforcing the regulatory environment.  The review 
will include identifying the regulatory support measures across the regulatory 
environments of the DCRAs. 
(iv)  Support the holding of an ad hoc forum among Asian Bond Markets Initiative 
(AMBI) Working Group (WG)4, rating agency security regulators for DCRAs, 
banking supervisors for Basel II,  and DCRAs in Asia as required. 
(v)  The  deliverables  for  (i)  and  (ii)  are  quarterly  monitoring  reports  and  a  final 
consolidated report on the status of the regulatory framework and compliance. 
 
C.  Credit Rating Agency Specialist (international, 5 person-months) 
3.  The specialist will conduct a survey to achieve the following: 
 
(i)  Compare the relative rankings of credit by DCRAs and  by global credit rating 
agencies (GCRA), using GCRA’s national rating scale methodologies against

Appendix 3  11 
DCRA rating scales, and compare the relative rankings to identify similarities and 
differences  of  significance,  and  to  arrive  at  some  useful  conclusions  on 
correlations and comparability. 
(ii)  Conduct a comparative study of the rating methodologies of selected DCRAs, 
determining  and  analyzing  the  critical  rating  factors  used  the  common  and 
different  rating  policies  and  practices  followed,  the  financial  and  operating 
benchmarks adopted and noting such other factors used by DCRAs in their credit 
rating process. 
(iii)  Identify common rating practices, methodologies, and DCRA policies. Construct 
a list of survey questions for DCRAs to determine the degree of conformity or 
disparity among them. Seek the cooperation of the DCRAs to supply the required 
information. 
(iv)  Analyze the DCRA rating databases and suggest a preliminary template to profile 
DCRA  rating  databases.  Seek  the  cooperation  of  the  DCRAs  to  supply  the 
required information. 
(v)  Assess the viability of DCRAs conducting default studies (if they have not already 
done so) by determining the age of the DCRA, the size of the rated portfolio, and 
the availability of annual rating reviews, among others. Investigate the degree of 
similarity or disparity in default rates against rating scales for DCRAs that have 
already published default studies. Identify the insights into the consistency of the 
rating performance (thus, peer performance) of DCRAs.  
 
D.   Financial Sector Project Expert (national, 5 person-months) 
4.  The expert will have the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Assist in coordinating workshops and best-practice dialogues with ACRAA. This 
task will, among others, involve 
(a)  assisting in the preparation and facilitation of the workshops and the best- 
practice  dialogues  and  maintaining  the  necessary  information  on  the 
workshops  and  the  best-practices  dialogues,  including  preparation  of 
training materials; 
(b)  undertaking internet searches and assisting in obtaining information on 
training  efforts  of  global  and  regional  rating  agencies,  and  analyzing  
necessary  capacity-building  themes  in  coordination  with  ACRAA  and 
other rating agencies; and 
(c)  collecting and disseminating information on training resources, materials, 
and  events  for  building  capacity,  through  websites  such  as 
AsianBondsOnline or the ACRAA website. 
 
(ii)  Assist  in  obtaining  information  on  activities  of  each  ACRAA  committee,  a 
Harmonization  of  Rating  Study  Group,  a  Basel  II  Accord  Compliance  Study 
Group, an ACRAA Website Committee, the Best Practice Committee, and the 
Training Committee. 
 
(iii)  Assist ACRAA in the development of harmonized rating studies, Basel II accord 
compliance, and best practices.  
 
(iv)  Assist in coordinating activities with the ASEAN+3 ABMI WG4 Rating Systems in 
organizing and facilitating seminars and forums.

OUTLINE OF THE STUDY  
ENHANCING COMPARABILITY AND HARMONIZATION  
AMONG DOMESTIC CREDIT RATING AGENCIES IN THE REGION 
 
 
1.   Analysis of the comparability of the relative rankings of credit by domestic credit rating 
agencies (DCRAs) and global credit rating agencies (GCRAs) 
 
(i)   Comparing GCRA national rating scales with DCRA rating scales  
(ii)   Comparing the relative ranking of corporations by DCRAS and GCRAs 
 
2.   Determinants analysis 
 
(i)  Comparison of financial ratios and benchmarks 
(a)  Identifying companies that are commonly rated by DCRAs and GCRAs 
(b)  Identifying the selected financial ratios for comparison 
(c)  Computing the financial ratios to facilitate comparison  
 
(ii)  Treatment of approach to key issues  
(a)  Questionnaires for DCRAs 
(b)  Identifying  common  rating  practices,  methodologies,  and  policies  among 
DCRAs 
 
3.  Viability of DCRAs default study (DS) 
 
(i)  Status of default study of DCRAs 
(a)  Disclosure status of DS by DCRAs 
(b)  Components of DS 
(1)  Collate ratings and default history over time—which will allow 
computation of default rates and transition matrixes 
(2)  Clearly define default and what events constitute defaults or rating 
downgrades 
 
(ii)  Assessment of DS:  
(a)  Coverage  of  information  disclosed  (number  of  rated  companies,  default 
histories, build default matrixes) 
(b)  Definitions of default  
(c)  Rules and policies   
(1)  Maintaining consistent policies and rating practices 
(2)  Tracking the annual performance of rated companies (and reviewing 
ratings on an annual basis), and regularly publishing  default studies  
 
(iii)  Challenge to the DS for comparability:  
(a)  Establish best practices via certain common criteria or standards (e.g., in 
corporate rating criteria, financial criteria, and treatment of key issues) 
(b)  Agreement to streamline divergent practices thorough IOSCO Code or 
similar code of conduct
